column4: Marriott Vacations buys ILG in $4.7 billion timeshare merger
column5: (Reuters) - Marriott Vacations Worldwide Corp VAC.N will buy timeshare operator ILG Inc ILG.O for $4.7 billion, the companies said on Monday, grabbing the chance to merge operations and brands spun out of Starwood and Marriott hotels.
column6: ILG serves some 2 million members through various networks and has faced pressure from investor FrontFour Capital Group, which has been urging a sale to cash in at a time when U.S. stock valuations are high and global travel demand is booming.
column7: The combined company will have 108 properties and seven upscale brands including ILG's Hyatt, Westin and Sheraton vacation ownership brands, giving it more scale to compete with Hilton Grand Vacations Inc HGV.N and Bluegreen Vacations Corp BXG.N.
column8: ILG’s stock rose about 5 percent on the news of the deal, while Marriott Vacations — paying $14.75 in cash and 0.165 of its own shares for each ILG share — slid 9.2 percent.
column9: “With the combination of the hotel groups – Starwood and Marriott – it only makes sense for the timeshares that operate those brands to merge,” Oppenheimer analyst Ian Zaffino said, adding that “timeshare growth is solid.”
column10: Hotel chain Marriott International Inc MAR.O bought Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc about two years ago in a $12 billion deal, months after Starwood spun off its timeshare business and merged it with ILG. Marriott spun off its timeshare business in 2011.
column11: Marriott Vacations’ deal for ILG comes as the timeshare industry seeks to improve occupancy rates and shed its image of locking customers into complex contracts, in the hope of becoming a more popular holiday option for many vacationers.
column12: The merger is expected to add to Marriott’s earnings and save at least $75 million in costs.
column13: “We see potential growth from the enhanced marketing capabilities across the expanded portfolio and owner and guest network that we will have post closing,” Marriott Vacations Chief Executive Officer Stephen Weisz said on a conference call with analysts.
column14: Marriott’s board of directors will be expanded to include two members from ILG’s board.
column15: According to Reuters’ calculations, the deal price represents a nearly 19 percent premium to ILG’s closing price on April 13, the day before Reuters reported that the two companies were in advanced talks for a deal.
column16: JPMorgan was Marriott’s exclusive financial adviser, while Goldman Sachs and Moelis & Co advised ILG.

column4: Marriott Vacations to buy ILG in $4.7 bln deal
column5: April 30 (Reuters) - Marriott Vacations Worldwide Corp said on Monday it would buy fellow vacation timeshare company ILG Inc in a cash and stock deal worth about $4.7 billion.
column6: ILG shareholders will receive $14.75 in cash and 0.165 shares of Marriott Vacations for each share, Marriott Vacations said.
column7: Reuters reported earlier this month that the two companies were in advanced talks over a deal. (Reporting by Arunima Banerjee in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: EXCLUSIVE-Marriott Vacations in the lead to clinch merger with ILG-sources
column5: April 16 (Reuters) - Marriott Vacations Worldwide Corp , a U.S. provider of vacation timeshare properties, is advanced discussions to merge with peer ILG Inc, according to people familiar with the matter.
column6: The deal would bring together two of the biggest vacation ownership companies, with brands including Marriott, Ritz-Carlton, Westin, Hyatt and Sheraton. The combined company would have more scale to compete other hotel-branded rivals, including Hilton Grand Vacations Inc and Bluegreen Vacations Corp.
column7: ILG views Marriott’s Vacations’ offer as the best it has received so far, and is engaged in negotiations to try to clinch a deal by the end of the month, the sources said. The talks could still end without any agreement, the sources added.
column8: The exact merger structure that Marriott Vacations and ILG are negotiating could not be learned.
column9: The sources asked not to be identified because the negotiations are confidential. Marriott Vacations and ILG did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
column10: ILG also explored a merger with Apollo Global Management LLC’s Diamond Resorts International Inc, sources said last month. Talks between ILG and Diamond Resorts have now ended, according to the sources. (Reporting by Greg Roumeliotis and Liana B. Baker in New York Editing by Nick Zieminski)
